narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: n/a
How to think about the environment from a humanities standpoint. We had a lot of super interesting readings that I enjoyed.

I gained a deeper understanding of the importance of the humanities in global issues, such as climate change. I think this course has shifted my perspective of how solutions to climate change are implemented, and it has made me appreciate questioning the effects of the implementation of scientific policy.
Close reading of various topics, ranging from IPCC reports to Indigenous experiences under climate change. Overall, I learned how to approach climate change from a non-STEM perspective.

The ability to deeply question how humanity engages with, and relates to, the world around us. Critically evaluating not only what environmental action has failed, but what academic and community action is necessary to construct positive, just, and effective environmental action.
Write a humanities paper, how to interact with abstract material

I learned incredibly valuable lenses through which to view the climate crisis. This class helped me with my writing but also my world view. It should be a mandatory course for anyone studying environmentalism.
Close reading analysis, essay writing, critical thinking skills on our role in the environment

I learned a magnanimity of valuable lessons in regards to the importance of the humanities when approaching climate change impacts. From geoengineering to evaluating IPCC reports, to conservation efforts, origin stories from a wide range of indigenous cultures, and more, this class was very eye-opening.

This course made me think critically about what environmentalism is and how we think about climate change. It really complicated a lot of fundamental assumptions made about the environment and nature in order to complicate the solutions we implement for environmental problems.

I improved by critical reading skills and seminar-based discussion skills. Through the readings and discussion, my preconceptions about nature and the ways humans engage with nature were challenged. I questioned the underlying assumptions I and other scientists have had about the environment, and learned to more clearly articulate my opinions on such topics. I was provided with many different perspectives through the coursework, and my writings skills were also further developed.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: n/a
I really enjoyed the course content, and I am glad that the readings were able to push me out of the realm of my knowledge to help me form new ideas.
The strength of this class is its small size and the high engagement of the students, along with the excellently curated reading list, and Professor Lindskog's expert moderation of class discussions.
Its fantastic none!
I felt that the readings were very engaging and paved the way for incredibly thought provoking class discussion. The assignments were paced well as well as the amount of work given.

Strengths- the in-class questions were very engaging and thought provoking. The workload was also very reasonable and allowed for enough time to develop our own perspectives on the readings in time for class.

Weakness-I wish we didn't rush through the close-reading of the books covered in class. I felt there was a lot more to breakdown that we didn't have time for.

This course introduced me to a variety of environmental humanities readings, including those from indigenous groups that I had never been exposed to before. The readings pushed my understanding of these topics in new ways. One weakness of the course was the limited style of assignments that we completed. I would have liked to write reading responses each week with a certain direction or instruction.

This class was very strong in discussions, readings, and the progression of topics. It was also a very warm and welcoming learning environment. Perhaps the only thing I would improve would be the guidance for the close reading paper, with maybe more time to practice close reading in class.

I felt that that this class was the most well-organized to facilitate student learning -- the challenge of assigning the right amount of work, such that the topics were engaging and rich but not overwhelming, was met, and in fact this course exemplified what a good syllabus should be for me. The readings were a manageable length and always brought in something new each class. I also loved the varying forms of media, including essays, movies, plays, and more. Because there are no pre-reqs, however, students could definitely be on different pages in terms of background knowledge, but I found that this brought interesting perspectives to the classrooms. Having taken a decent amount of environmental courses, I did feel that I was better able to offer insights/opinions -- maybe I would recommend this course to older students. We had reading responses due each week, which I think were good for promoting thoughtful reading, but seemed a little disjointed from the classroom. On the other hand, our paper topics were tied in very intentionally. Perhaps there could be other small assignments that would be more engaging.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: n/a
Absolutely. Dr. Lindskog is an absolute gem and the sweetest professor ever. Going to class and listening to other students opinions are so interesting.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. This course pulls together many different perspectives and disciplines to allow for productive discussions of climate change. If you are not confident in your ability to contribute to conversations due to lack of knowledge, this course will guide you and show how many different backgrounds can be important to the class discussions.
Absolutely! The class readings felt meaningful yet manageable to digest, and Professor Lindskog breaks down the complex topics discussed in class in such a clarifying way.

Absolutely. This class will force you to deeply critique all of your pre-held conceptions about what being a "good environmentalist" looks like, or even what "the environment" means, and how we should relate to it. These are not just academic questions - you will walk away with an understanding of the profound implications of these questions as societies make critical decisions for development and future action in the face of the climate crisis.
Yes. Makes u take a different perspective and profoundly think
Absolutely. This class was such a pleasure to be in and I felt that I gained real world knowledge as well as technical (writing and reading).
Absolutely. Professor Lindskog is amazing. Period. Life-changing class.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in different perspectives on the environment.

Yes! It is offers a really critical and helpful lens of environmental humanities to climate change science and discourse. The structure really helps create a strong foundation that can be built upon as topics get more complicated and ambiguous.

I loved this course so much, and as a senior, could easily say it was my favorite course at Yale. Students in this class seemed to really thoroughly digest the material through the discussions, and always had something interesting to say. Furthermore, students were constantly referencing previous classes' readings, a sign of consistent engagement and a reflection on the quality/organization of the assigned work. A warm and personal classroom environment was established via check ins at the start of every class, which made everyone much friendlier and more willing to participate. I always looked forward to attending this class and doing the readings! I felt like I received a very comprehensive education on the environmental humanities, and left with a new foundation/lens for environmental science. I think anyone interested in the environment, from any perspective, would benefit from this class, since we challenged basic assumptions and discussed the environment from so many different angles/mediums.
